utterances: Despite her concerns as Diane Peranich looks out over the trees in War Memorial Park, she has faith Pass Christian will survive.
State Rep.
PERANICH: But you see, they took a terrible beating these magnificent oaks, but they didn't go over.
Maybe we are like oak trees.
We certainly are people that endure.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.
Two concessions today from two Republicans and the Democrats get set to take over the United States Senate.
This afternoon Virginia Senator George Allen acknowledged that his rival was the winner of the contest there.
Today, I've called and congratulated Jim Webb and his team for their victory.
They had the prevailing winds.
Earlier in the day, Republican Conrad Burns conceded his Senate race to Democrat Jon Tester.
At the Capitol today, Senate Democrats held a small rally to celebrate their takeover of both houses of Congress.
Here's a sample of what Senator Richard Durbin had to say.
Millions of people spoke on Tuesday night and we heard the message.
The message is America can do better.
We can come together on a bipartisan basis to solve the real problems facing our country.
Coming together on a bipartisan basis was the order of the day at the White House.
President Bush hosted the next speaker of the House of Representatives, Democrat Nancy Pelosi, for lunch.
Both told reporters in the Oval Office they would do what's best for the country, though they both acknowledged the differences in philosophy that separate them.
NPR's Don Gonyea reports.
It seems it was just yesterday that the president and the congresswoman were sniping at one another in the midst of a fierce political campaign.
Okay, so maybe it wasn't yesterday, but here's the president in Arkansas on Monday, the day before the election, delivering a cutting joke about Pelosi that was a staple of his midterm stump speech.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: They asked the lady who thinks she's going to be the speaker, but she's not -
(Soundbite of applause)
#NAME?
The president regularly portrayed the Democrats and their leader as soft on taxes, terrorism and national security, at one point saying if Democrats win, America loses.
Pelosi has shown she can dish it out as well.
She's portrayed President Bush as dangerous, as being in denial, as an emperor with no clothes.
Here she is in an interview on CBS's 60 Minutes program last month when Leslie Stahl asked her about calling the president incompetent.
(Soundbite of show, ""60 Minutes"")
This isn't personal.
This is about -
It sounds personal.
This isn't personal.
He's incompetent.
Well, I think he is.
That's personal.
Well, I'm sorry.
That's his problem.
But with the election now over, the president and the speaker to be are making nice.
First I want to congratulate Congresswoman Pelosi for becoming the speaker of the House and the first woman speaker of the House.
This is historic for our country, and as a father of young women, I think it's important.
I really do.
We both extended the hand of friendship, a partnership to solve the problems facing our country, the challenges that America's working families face.
Also on hand at the luncheon at the White House today were the leaders' number twos, Vice President Cheney for Mr. Bush and Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer of Maryland for Pelosi.
Hoyer made brief comments echoing Pelosi's.
Cheney did not speak.
Such occasions are all part of the necessary ritual after a scene-changing election says political scientist Ross Baker of Rutgers University.
Well, you know, it's a little bit like a wedding toast.
You know, everybody's hopeful that the marriage will succeed and the toasts are very hopeful, but it really remains to be seen.
And today, while neither nor the congresswoman took questions from reporters, each was quick to acknowledge differences.
I look forward to working in a confidence building way with the president, recognizing that we have our differences and we will debate them, and that is what our founders intended.
We're going to work together to address those challenges in a constructive way.
We won't agree on every issue but we do agree that we love America equally, that we're concerned about the future of this country.
And Rutgers Professor Baker says there may indeed be an early opportunity to find some common ground on such issues as immigration or raising the minimum wage.
Much more difficult, of course, are the tax cuts the president wants to make permanent and which the Democrats want to revise and redirect toward the middle class.
Tougher still will be Iraq, where the White House maintains that it will not agree to any plan or compromise that would have U.S.
troops withdraw before the Iraqi government is ready and able to provide for security in the country.
But for now, at least both sides have a chance to let the wounds of the election season heal before resuming their old conflicts in the New Year.
Don Gonyea, NPR News, the White House.
We're going to move on to another of the many challenges facing Iraq now.
The country's central bank is in the middle of the most significant modernization in its history.
If all goes according to plan, the country will soon move from an almost entirely cash-based economy to one with most of the features of the modern financial system.
As NPR's Adam Davidson reports, this is seen as a crucial step for Iraq's economy because without a better banking system, major development projects are more difficult.
Look, for about 15 years now, we've been told over and over again, and especially by the parties that are the most alarmist, that Iran is on the brink of having nuclear weapons.
Most recently, Secretary Gates, whom I trust, said it could be anywhere from one to three years.
Well, one year is fairly close, but it certainly gives us more time than just negotiating for a few weeks or even for two or three months.
Zbigniew Brzezinski, thank you very much for talking with us.
Nice to have been with you.
Dr.
Brzezinski, former national security advisor, is now with the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, D.C.
And one final note on Iran.
The country's foreign minister visited Washington today.
It is the first time in years an Iranian official has visited the capital, though the State Department could not say exactly how long it's been.
A department spokesman said Foreign Minister Manouchehr Mottaki would not be meeting any representatives of the U.S.
government.
He was given permission to visit the Pakistani embassy, which handles Iranian interests here.
And you can hear an interview with Mottaki tomorrow on MORNING EDITION.
It's more than a week now since Hurricane Gustav made landfall.
New Orleans was spared a direct hit.
But just 80 miles away, in Baton Rouge, Gustav caused more damage to utilities than any other storm before.
About half of the state's capital city remains without power.
We're joined by the mayor of Baton Rouge, Kip Holden.
He's also the president of East Baton Rouge Parish.
Thanks for being with us.
Thank you very much.
And Mayor Holden, why is it that so many people there are still without power?
Well, we've been asking the same questions.
There was tremendous damage to the transmission lines.
We're watching a lot of things that have occurred that really during some of the worst storms never happened before.
Was that a surprise to you that Gustav turned out to be so damaging there?
Yes, it was, because we were mainly set up as a sheltering city.
So it took us all by surprise when for a period of maybe four to five hours we had winds of 50 to 60 miles an hour, gusting as high as 91 miles per hour at the airport.
